facts.text: Civil Misc. Petition NO. 530 of 1959 filed under s. 10 of the Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874 for cancellation of decree dated November 25, 1949 granted to the respondent by Privy Council Appeal No. XI of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Misc. Petition NO. 530 of 1959. Petition for cancellation of the decree dated November 25, 1949, granted to the Respondent by the Order-in-Council in Privy Council Appeal No. XI of 1948.

facts.text: Decree dated November 25, 1949 granted to respondent by Order-in-Council in Privy Council Appeal No. XI of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Petition for cancellation of the decree dated November 25, 1949, granted to the Respondent by the Order-in-Council in Privy Council Appeal No. XI of 1948. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General for India and B. R. L. Iyengar, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petition seeks cancellation of decree insofar as it operates on office of Patilki and 11 Watan lands at Kirtgeri in Taluk of Gadag.

anchor.surface_text: This petition has been made under s. 10 of the Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874  hereinafter called the Act , for cancellation of the decree granted to the respondent by the Order in Council dated November 25, 1949, in so far as the said decree purports to operate on or include any right to the office of the Patilki and 11 Watan lands attached thereto.

facts.text: 11 Watan lands at Kirtgeri form part of Watan, assigned as remuneration to officiator under s. 23 of the Act per revenue records.

anchor.surface_text: These lands are situated at Kirtgeri in the Taluk of Gadag. They form part of a Watan and, according to the revenue records, they have been assigned as remuneration to the officiator for the time being under s. 23 of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner obtained certificate under s. 10 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has obtained a certificate prescribed under s. 10, and he companytends that as a result of the said certificate this Court should cancel the decree as claimed by him in the petition.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit against petitioner in Court of First Class Sub Judge at Dharwar, Civil Suit No. 18 of 1934, claiming partition and possession as adopted son of Shiddangouda.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent had filed a suit against the petitioner in the Court of the First Class Sub Judge at Dharwar  Civil Suit No. 18 of 1934  and in the said suit he had claimed partition and possession of the properties as an adopted son of Shiddangouda.

facts.text: Properties in suit were and are in possession of petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: These properties were and are in the possession of the petitioner. The trial companyrt passed a decree in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Trial court (First Class Sub Judge at Dharwar) passed decree in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt passed a decree in favour of the respondent. The petitioner then preferred an appeal, No. 182 of 1935, in the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioner appealed to Bombay High Court, Appeal No. 182 of 1935, appeal allowed, trial court decree reversed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then preferred an appeal, No. 182 of 1935, in the High Court of Bombay. His appeal was allowed and the decree passed by the trial companyrt was reversed.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Privy Council, Appeal No. 11 of 1948, appeal allowed, trial court decree restored.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then challenged the High Court decree and went up to the Privy Council in Appeal No. 11 of 1948. His appeal was allowed, and the Privy Council held that the decree passed by the trial companyrt should be restored.

facts.text: Order-in-Council dated November 25, 1949 entitled respondent to half share in properties by partition, mesne profits past and future till recovery or three years, enquiry directed.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly an Order-in-Council was drawn up on November 25, 1949 under this order the respondent was entitled to recover by partition a half share in the properties in suit. He was also entitled to mesne profits, past and future, till the recovery of possession or three years and an enquiry was directed in that behalf.

facts.text: 11 lands in question included among properties respondent entitled to share.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the properties in which the respondent had thus become entitled to claim a share are the 11 lands in question.

facts.text: Respondent filed execution application Darkhast No. 41 of 1950 in Subordinate Judge at Dharwar.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse the respondent filed an execution application Darkhast No. 41 of 1950, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge at Dharwar.

facts.text: Petitioner contended 11 lands governed by Act, assigned to Patil office, inalienable, not partitionable; no claim to office in original suit.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then companytended that the 11 lands in question were governed by the provisions of the Act, they were assigned as remuneration to the office of the Patil, and as such they companyld number be partitioned. It was also urged on his behalf that in the original suit the respondent had number claimed any declaration that he was entitled to the office of Patil and that without such a claim the 11 lands in question companyld number be claimed by the respondent.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for and obtained certificate under s.10 from Collector addressed to Civil Judge Senior Division Dharwar.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the execution proceedings the petitioner applied for the grant of the prescribed certificate under s. 10 of the Act, and a certificate was accordingly issued by the Collector addressed to the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Dharwar.

facts.text: Executing court cancelled execution process against Patilki-assigned property of Kirtgeri based on certificate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the said companyrt acted upon the certificate and cancelled the execution process which had been issued against the Patilki-assigned property of Kirtgeri.

facts.text: Respondent challenged cancellation order to Bombay High Court, challenge upheld following Rachapa v. Amingouda; certificate invalid as addressed to Civil Judge not Privy Council; execution to proceed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the said order before the Bombay High Court and his challenge was upheld by the said High Court. The High Court followed its own earlier Full Bench decision in Rachapa v. Amingouda  1  and held that the certificate issued by the Collector under s. 10 was invalid in that it was addressed number to the Privy Council which was the companyrt which passed the decree but to the Civil Judge at Dharwar.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for reissue of certificate under s.10 addressed to Supreme Court as successor to Privy Council; certificate issued January 13, 1958 by Assistant Commissioner Gadag Division.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the petitioner applied for a reissue of a certificate under s. 10 and prayed that the certificate  1   1881  V BOM. 283. should be addressed to this Court as in the meanwhile the Privy Council had ceased to have any jurisdiction and this Court had become its successor. A certificate has accordingly been issued on January 13, 1958, addressed to this Court.

facts.text: Certificate states property assigned as remuneration to Patil office, inalienable, not liable to civil court process; attachment to be removed, decree cancelled re said property.

anchor.surface_text: The certificate says that the property in question has been assigned as remuneration to the office of Patil and as such it is inalienable and number liable to process of civil companyrt and so the process of attachment levied against the said property should be removed and the decree in so far as it relates to the said property should be cancelled.

facts.text: Respondent appealed certificate to Deputy Commissioner Dharwar, appeal failed, certificate confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that after this certificate was issued by the Assistant Commissioner, Gadag Division, the respondent filed an appeal to the Deputy Commissioner, Dharwar. His appeal, however, failed and the certificate issued by the Assistant Commissioner has been companyfirmed.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds certificate valid as addressed to successor court; res judicata argument rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We are number impressed by this argument. What the Bombay High Court has held is that the certificate must be issued to the companyrt which passed the decree, and if in law this Court can be said to- be in effect and in substance the Court that pssed the decree then the Certificate must be held to be perfectly valid.

facts.text: Supreme Court is successor to Privy Council via Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act 1949 (appointed day Oct 10, 1949), Federal Court, Constitution Arts 374, 135.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 of the Abolition of the Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949, has provided, inter alia, that as from the appointed day which was October 10, 1949, the jurisdiction of His Majesty in Council to entertain appeals and petitionsfrom or in respect of any judgment, decree or order of any companyrt or tribunal within the territory of India shall cease save hereinafter provided.

facts.text: Properties governed by Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, assigned as remuneration to Patilki office; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the properties in respect of which the certificate has been issued are properties assigned as remuneration to Patilki I office and are governed by the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: If certificate valid under s.10, court must cancel decree re covered properties; objection to address overruled.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companyceded that if the certificate is duly issued under s. 10 of the Act it makes it obligatory on the companyrt to cancel the decree in regard to the properties companyered by the certificate.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows petition, cancels decree insofar as it purports to operate on Patilki office and watan lands at Kirtgeri per certificate.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the petition is allowed and the decree in question in so far as it purports to operate on or include any right to the office of Patilki and watan lands attached thereto at Kirtgeri as enumerated in the certificate is cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it has been urged before us that the decision of the Bombay High Court operates as res judicata and so, in view of the said decision, the present certificate also should be held to be invalid. The argument is that the effect of the decision of the Bombay High Court is that the certificate should have been addressed to the Privy Council, and since it is addressed to this Court it is invalid. We are not impressed by this argument.

anchor.surface_text: The next relevant provisions are contained in Art. 374 and Art. 135 of the Constitution. Art. 374 2  provides that all suits, appeals and proceedings, Civil or Criminal pending in the Federal Court at the commencement of the Constitution, shall stand removed to the Supreme Court, and the Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the same and the judgments and orders of the Federal 29 Court delivered or made before the commencement of the Constitution shall have the same force and effect ,as if they had been delivered or made by the Supreme Court.

concepts.interpretation: Judgments and orders of Federal Court have same force as if by Supreme Court; relevant for treating Privy Council order as Supreme Court decree

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to Art. 135. This article provides that until Parliament by law otherwise provides the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of Art. 133 or Art. 134 do not apply, if jurisdiction and powers in relation to that matter were exercisable by the Federal Court imme- diately before the commencement of this Constitution under any existing law.

concepts.interpretation: Supreme Court inherits Federal Court's jurisdiction including over petitions like the present one

issues.text: Whether the decree granted to the respondent by the Order in Council dated November 25, 1949 should be cancelled under s. 10 of the Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874 in so far as the said decree purports to operate on or include any right to the office of the Patilki and 11 Watan lands attached thereto

anchor.surface_text: s. 10 of the Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874  hereinafter called the Act , for cancellation of the decree granted to the respondent by the Order in Council dated November 25, 1949, in so far as the said decree purports to operate on or include any right to the office of the Patilki and 11 Watan lands attached thereto.

issues.text: Whether the decision of the Bombay High Court operates as res judicata such that the present certificate under s. 10 should be held to be invalid

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it has been urged before us that the decision of the Bombay High Court operates as res judicata and so, in view of the said decision, the present certificate also should be held to be invalid. The argument is that the effect of the decision of the Bombay High Court is that the certificate should have been addressed to the Privy Council, and since it is addressed to this Court it is invalid. We are not impressed by this argument.

issues.text: Whether this Court can, in view of the constitutional changes which have taken place in the meantime, be said to be the Court that has passed the present decree

anchor.surface_text: What the Bombay High Court has held is that the certificate must be issued to the court which passed the decree, and if in law this Court can be said to- be in effect and in substance the Court that pssed the decree then the Certificate must be held to be perfectly valid. Therefore, there is no substance in the argument of res judicata. The main question which falls to be considered is whether this Court can, in view of the constitutional changes which have taken place in the meantime, be said to be the Court that has passed the present decree.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 provides, inter alia, that when it shall appear to the Collector that by virtue of, or in execution of, a decree or order of any court any watan or any part thereof ... cancel the decree or order complained of so far as it concerns

holdings.text: We are not impressed by this argument. [...] Therefore, there is no substance in the argument of res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it has been urged before us that the decision of the Bombay High Court operates as res judicata and so, in view of the said decision, the present certificate also should be held to be invalid. The argument is that the effect of the decision of the Bombay High Court is that the certificate should have been addressed to the Privy Council, and since it is addressed to this Court it is invalid. We are not impressed by this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The certificate must be addressed to the court which passed the decree; Supreme Court is in effect and substance that court, so prior High Court decision on address does not bind via res judicata.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the petitioner. [...] We, therefore, feel no doubt that as a result of the relevant statutory provisions to which we have referred the certificate issued in the present case to this Court is valid and must be given effect to.

anchor.surface_text: What the Bombay High Court has held is that the certificate must be issued to the court which passed the decree, and if in law this Court can be said to- be in effect and in substance the Court that pssed the decree then the Certificate must be held to be perfectly valid. Therefore, there is nosubstance in the argument of res judicata. The main question which falls to be companysidered is whether this Court can,. in view of the companystitutional changes which have taken place in the meantime, be said to be the Court that has passed the present decree.- In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory succession: Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act 1949 ss.2,4,5,8 transfers Privy Council orders to Federal Court; Constitution Art.374(2) equates Federal Court orders to Supreme Court; Art.135 transfers Federal Court jurisdiction to Supreme Court.

holdings.text: It is also conceded that if the certificate is duly issued under s. 10 of the Act it makes it obligatory on the court to cancel the decree in regard to the properties covered by the certificate. [...] Since we have overruled that objection it follows that portion of the decree which concerns the watan properties must be cancelled.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Certificate validly issued under s.10 Bombay Hereditary Offices Act; properties are watan assigned under s.23; s.10 mandates cancellation of decree insofar as it affects such properties.

holdings.text: In the result the petition is allowed and the decree in question in so far as it purports to operate on or include any right to the office of Patilki and watan lands attached thereto at Kirtgeri as enumerated in the certificate is cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it has been urged before us that the decision of the Bombay High Court operates as res judicata and so, in view of the said decision, the present certificate also should be held to be invalid. The argument is that the effect of the decision of the Bombay High Court is that the certificate should have been addressed to the Privy Council, and since it is addressed to this Court it is invalid. We are not impressed by this argument.

In the result the petition is allowed and the decree in question in so far as it purports to operate on or include any right to the office of Patilki and watan lands attached thereto at Kirtgeri as enumerated in the certificate

anchor.surface_text: What the Bombay High Court has held is that the certificate must be issued to the court which passed the decree, and if in law this Court can be said to- be in effect and in substance the Court that pssed the decree then the Certificate must be held to be perfectly valid. Therefore, there is nosubstance in the argument of res judicata. The main question which falls to be companysidered is whether this Court can,. in view of the companystitutional changes which have taken place in the meantime, be said to be the Court that has passed the present decree.- In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the petitioner.

In the result the petition is allowed and the decree in question in so far as it purports to operate on or include any right to the office of Patilki and watan lands attached thereto at Kirtgeri as enumerated in the certificate
